residentialschool.caption: Classroom at the Old Sun Indian Residential School, Blackfoot Reserve in Gleichen, Alberta, Canada, 1945. Conditions were especially harsh at these religious boarding schools in the US and Canada, set up to forcibly “civilize” Native American or First Nations children.

purplehands.caption: In the belief that the left hand was the devil’s hand, nuns sometimes punished left-handed children at residential schools by tying one or both wrists, dangerously constricting bloodflow and causing the hands to turn purple.
purplehands.alt: Students posing with nuns have their left hands tied. The hands are visibly purple.

manos.caption: Stenciled hands at the Cueva de las Manos (“Cave of the Hands”) in Argentina, created in waves between 7,300 BCE and 700 CE. Left hands predominate, indicating a right-handed majority in pre-Columbian South America (as people will generally use their dominant hand to hold the painting tool, here probably a bone spray pipe).
manos.alt: A cave wall covered with the painted outlines of hands.

iamesnaylor.caption: In 1656, English Quaker James Naylor was publicly tortured and branded on the forehead with a “B” for blasphemer.

naylor2.caption: “Iames Nailor Quaker set 2 howers on the Pillory at Westminster, whiped by the Hang man to the old Exchainge London, Som dayes after, Stood too howers more on the Pillory at the Exchainge, and there had his Tongue Bored throug with a hot Iron, & Stigmatized in the Forehead with the Letter: B: Decem: 17 anno Dom:1656:”
naylor2.alt: The whipping of James Nailor and his stigmatizing.

What about homosexual citizens?” and “The American Way: Employment based upon competence, ability, training; not upon private life” and “an inalienable right the pursuit of happiness - for homosexuals too!!” and “homosexual citizens want equal treatment as human beings.”

bergonicchair.caption: The “Bergonic chair,” a World War I era device “for giving general electric treatment for psychological effect, in psycho-neurotic cases.”
bergonicchair.alt: A nurse in a white uniform stands next to a complex mechanical apparatus with multiple tubes, dials, and gauges. She adjusts one of the settings with her hand. Lying on a reclined chair next to her is a male patient, attached to the machine via wires.

heathlab.caption: Diagram of Dr. Robert Galbraith Heath’s lab at Tulane University showing the patient and instrument room, ca. 1954.
heathlab.alt: A diagram of Heath’s lab. It shows a laboratory with three rooms, the leftmost is filled with devices, the middle contains a patient lying on a gurney, who appears to have wires attached to his head leading to the instruments in the first room. A man in a lab coat sits next to the patient. In a third room a camera on a tripod records the scene.

headpiece.caption: Photographs of a patient who underwent Heath’s Deep Brain Stimulation therapy for schizophrenia, showing the plastic headpiece with an electrode connector exposed (left) and with dressing (right), ca. 1954.
headpiece.alt: Two photos showing a headpiece mounted to a man with a shaved head. The first photo shows the headpiece and the back of the head, while the second one shows the headpiece and head wrapped in tape.

kinseyscale.caption: The Kinsey Scale, as first published in Kinsey et al., Sexual Behavior in the Human Male, 1948.
kinseyscale.alt: A diagram showing a six-step scale from 0, fully heterosexual, to 6, fully homosexual, and gradual steps between showing different degrees of mixed hetero and homosexuality.

acebi.caption: Sketch of a 2D sexual attraction scale, showing how asexuality and bisexuality can be modeled as a continuum.
acebi.alt: This hand-sketched diagram has two axes, same-sex attraction from low to high, and opposite-sex attraction from low to high. The diagonal region is shaded, and in the low same- and opposite- sex attraction region, it says asexual. Under high same- and opposite-sex attraction, it says bisexual. Note these two labeled regions are connected, implying there is a gradient between the two. Under high same-sex and low opposite-sex attraction, the region is labeled heterosexual. Under high opposite-sex and low same-sex attraction, it says heterosexual. The hetero- and homo- sexual regions are separated with dashed lines suggesting there is not a single cut-off between the regions.

vintagelesbian.caption: A couple on a porch in Germantown, New York, 1977.
vintagelesbian.alt: Two women are leaning on a pillar, smiling at each other.

vintagelesbians2.caption: Lovers, date unknown.
vintagelesbians2.alt: A weathered photograph of two women relaxing atop a large rock outdoors. One woman lies on her back, held by the other, who looks down at her face, smiling.

avioniii.caption: Ader Avion III, an experimental steam-powered monoplane designed and built by Clément Ader between 1892 and 1897, France.
avioniii.alt: An old, experimental aircraft that appears to be made of canvas and metal tubing.

supersonic.caption: The Concorde's maiden flight, Fairford, Gloucestershire, England, April 10, 1969.
supersonic.alt: The Concorde aircraft flies low in the sky over a crowd of onlookers standing in the street below. The streamlined aircraft juxtaposes with the black and chrome mid-century cars stopped in the street.

mandarinduck.caption: An adult male mandarin duck.
mandarinduck.alt: A brightly multi-colored and textured mandarin duck.

kinseyspring.caption: Sketch of a 2D sexual attraction scale, where a person’s “default position” is a point, and an elliptical region around the point illustrates their “flexibility.”
kinseyspring.alt: This hand-sketched diagram has two axes, same-sex attraction from low to high, and opposite-sex attraction from low to high. The plot shows the region divided into regions labeled “homoflexible,” “bisexual,” “bi-comfortable,” “heterosexual,” “demi-sexual,” and “asexual,” showing that one can loosely organize various sexual identities across the degree to which a person experiences high or low same- and opposite-sex attraction. It also indicates a spectrum from asexual to demisexual to bisexual along the diagonal.

mccarthycosmo.caption: Painting for Cosmo, 1971, by Frank McCarthy.
mccarthycosmo.alt: A shirtless man holds a woman wearing a pink dress. He clasps her closely while she pushes away on his chest, her head leaned back. Overlaid in the foreground, roman chariots are racing.

italiaandgermania.caption: Italia und Germania by Johann Friedrich Overbeck, 1828.
italiaandgermania.alt: An intimate scene of two women, presumably representing Italy and Germany, who are sitting closely together, holding hands and leaning towards each other.

wildedouglas.caption: Oscar Wilde and Lord Alfred Douglas, May 1893.
wildedouglas.alt: A studio photograph of Oscar Wilde and Lord Alfred Douglas.

warpeddesire.caption: Cover of a 1960 pulp novel, Warped Desire.
warpeddesire.alt: In the background of the bookcover, a woman is undressing, her curly hair is down. In the foreground, presumably the same woman is seated, her hair tied up and wearing a shirt, smoking a cigarette. The cover is titled “Warped Desire” and subtitled “...boldly probes the problem of the frigid woman, forced by her own desperation into unnatural paths.”

lesbianbarmap.caption: The 21 remaining lesbian bars in the US in 2021.

lesbianbarproject.caption: Comedian Lea DeLaria and Cubby Hole owner Lisa Menichino in the 2021 documentary The Lesbian Bar Project.
lesbianbarproject.alt: Lea DeLaria and Cubby Hole owner Lisa Menichino clink shot glasses together in the colorfully and eclectically decorated lesbian bar Cubby Hole.

erotisme.caption: Attitudes Passionnelles: Erotisme (“Passionate Erotic Poses”), from the Salpêtrière asylum in Paris, 1878. Photograph by Paul-Marie-Léon Regnard in J.M. Charcot’s Iconographie photographique de la Salpêtrière.

londonbrothel.caption: One of Victorian London's secret brothels, from The Swell’s Night Guide Through the Metropolis, 1841.
londonbrothel.alt: Men and women in Victorian attire dancing and lounging in an opulent room.

sexworker.caption: Portrait of a sex worker, Storyville, New Orleans, by E.J. Bellocq, ca. 1912.
sexworker.alt: In this vintage photograph a woman is seated on a carved wooden chair. Her legs are crossed and she leans on a table next to her, upon which a bottle of rye is prominently placed. She is holding a partially filled glass with her right arm and is wearing black and white striped leggings and a dress that reveals her arms and left shoulder.

dansemacabre.caption: MK: excluded the image on the web, following the book

syphilis.caption: Illustration of severe syphilitic lesions by Christopher D'Alton, 1862.
syphilis.alt: This medical illustration portrays a face which consumed by lesions from the chin to the  nose, as well as the left temple and eyebrow. The legions are nearly black, with red inflammation at the periphery.

syphilisdeathbed.caption: French caricature of a syphilitic man on his deathbed lamenting the cause of his illness, ca. 1800–1810.
syphilisdeathbed.alt: A bedridden, gaunt man stares away in lamentation while raising his arms at two women, faces covered in red pockmarks hinting at disease, who stare back at him and point at him, perhaps with pity or accusation, as they leave the room.

antimasturbationpatent.caption: “This invention relates to [...] the treatment of the male organs in the cure for involuntary emissions from any cause or [can be] used as a preventive for self-abuse or masturbation frequently practiced by weak-minded boys or young men.” It uses “spikes, electric shocks, and an alarm bell [to] [...] punish the wearer.” Albert V. Todd, US Patent No. 745,264, 1903.
antimasturbationpatent.alt: The patent diagram depicts a contraption resembling a belt with an apparatus at the middle of it. The elaborate device seems to contain springs, pins, and spikes.

pronounpins.caption: Pronoun pins from a 2016 art and technology festival in Portland, Oregon.
pronounpins.alt: Four bright pink pronoun pins. Around the edge of each, it says “Pronouns,” in the center of each it says, respectively, “They/Them,” “She/Her,” “He/Him,” and “Ask Me!”

zzyym.caption: MK: excluded the image on the web, following the book

intersexbirthcert.caption: Sara Kelly Keenan’s birth certificate, the first in the US to say “Intersex.” It was issued in 2016, when she was 55 years old.
intersexbirthcert.alt: A tight-cropped photo of a birth certificate which has “Intersex” printed beneath the Sex box.

binoculars.caption: Cover art of pulp novel The Nude Who Did by Ted Mark, 1970. Artwork by Stanley Borack.
binoculars.alt: A man appears to be looking through binoculars at a heterosexual couple making love.

homology.caption: “Three stages in the differentiation of external genital organs. The male and the female organs have the same beginnings and are homologous with one another.” Money, Man & Woman, Boy & Girl, 44, 1972.
homology.alt: A detailed medical diagram shows three stages of differentiation of a baby’s external genital organs. It shows how there is a common sexual appearance of the baby at the second to third month of pregnancy which then starts to differentiate (between a vulval groove and urethral groove) at the third to fourth month of pregnancy to finally the fully formed external genital organs at the time of birth.

quigley.caption: The Quigley Scale, proposed in 1995, is a phenotypic grading system defining seven classes between “fully masculinized” and “fully feminized” genitals.
quigley.alt: This animation shows a six-point scale that shows at one extreme, step 1, a fully formed penis, and at the other extreme, step 6, a fully formed vagina. The intermediate steps shows how the genitals increasingly morph as the penis shrinks into the clitoris and the scrotum begins to separate into a labia.

nettiestevens.caption: Nettie Stevens (1861–1912), American geneticist who discovered sex chromosones, at the Naples Zoological Station, 1909.
nettiestevens.alt: Nettie Stevens looks into a microscope.

chimeras.caption: Chimerism in a rose, a cat, and singer-songwriter Taylor Muhl.

chimericrose.caption: Chimerism in a rose.
chimericrose.alt: A chimeric rose appears perfectly split where one side is a pristine white and the other is a deep magenta.

chimericcat.caption: Chimerism in a cat.
chimericcat.alt: A chimeric cat whose right side is orange with an orange eye, and its left side is black with a striking blue eye. The two colors are split as if by a single line running perfectly down the middle.

chimericpeacock.caption: Gynandromorphic peacock, Sydney, 2007.
chimericpeacock.alt: A chimeric peacock. The right half of its feathers are entirely white while the left half are the traditional brown, green, and blue hues.

taylormuhl.caption: Chimerism in singer-songwriter Taylor Muhl (1983–).
taylormuhl.alt: A person's upper body showing chimerism with two distinct skin color tones split down the middle.

ais.caption: Group photo of people with Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome and related intersex conditions, 2010.
ais.alt: A group photo of feminine presenting people across many ages.

file_print: Hammond - Sexual impotence in the male - Preface - 1883.jpg
file_web: Hammond - Sexual impotence in the male - Preface - 1883-Enhanced EDIT + Noise 3-5.webp
file_web_thb: Hammond - Sexual impotence in the male - Preface - 1883-Enhanced EDIT + Noise 3-5.webp
hammondpreface.caption: Preface to Hammond, Sexual Impotence in the Male, 1883.
hammondpreface.alt: “As its title shows, this little book relates solely to sexual impotence as it exists in the male. At some future time I propose to enlarge its scope so as to include the subject of sterility, and to consider both these affections as they occur in men and women. 43 West Fifty-fourth Street, New York, May 15th, 1883.”

hypospadiasbefore.caption: “Patient reared as female and attended fashionable girls' school until age of 20. Hypospadic phallus, with which patient had sexual relations, as a male, with girls in school; then suspected for first time that true sex was male.”
hypospadiasbefore.alt: Medical illustration accompanying the case study portrays “testes undescended,” “glans penis,” “redundant foreskin,” and “pseudo labia.”

hypospadiasafter.caption: “Numerous operations to cure abnormalities successful. Patient married his hospital nurse; intercourse satisfactory to both.” From Young, Genital Abnormalities, Hermaphroditism and Related Adrenal Diseases, 52, 1937.
hypospadiasafter.alt: Medical illustration titled “Condition after final operation” shows a reconstructed penis, with annotations pointing to the “urinary meatus,” “scar,” and “small fistula.”

enlargedclitoris.caption: Brought up in a male orphanage and admitted aged 7 with a “small, hypospadic” penis, patient F.R. was found to have a vagina, uterus, Fallopian tube, and supposed left ovary, leading the doctors to conclude F.R. was “definitely female,” with unfortunate consequences: “Child put into girl’s clothing; transferred to female orphanage. Developed marked habit of masturbation; on this account enlarged “clitoris” was amputated. At age of 17, operation for hernia: discovery that supposed ovary was testicle. This was removed. Patient again assumed male clothing [... and] has become more masculine in character and interests. He has taken the name of  “John,” and is employed as a truck driver.” From Young, 84–87.
enlargedclitoris.alt: Two-part medical illustration titled “Condition on admission, Oct. 13, 1925” shows two views of the patient's genitalia. Annotations point to the “phallus,” “vaginal outlet,” and “labia majora (testes not found)” among others.

anniesprinkle.caption: American sexologist, performance artist, former sex worker, and sex work advocate Annie Sprinkle.

linguistic.caption: “Designative and Dynamic Words” from Money, Venuses Penuses, 69, 1986.
linguistic.alt: A text graphic detailing two sets of suffixes. (1) The suffixes “-ive” and “-iveness” are described as implying “illustrating or being an example of the process or source designated by the root”. (2) The suffixes “-ivity”, “-uality”, “-ual”, “-(a/e)nce”, and “-(a/e)nt” are described as implying “manifesting or being operated by powers or capacities characteristic of the process or source designated by the root”.

reimerselfportrait.caption: Self-portrait by the young Bruce/Brenda/David Reimer.
reimerselfportrait.alt: A painting of a child. Dark smears cover the child, partially obscuring the face.

moneycover.caption: Drawings on the cover of Money and Ehrhardt, Man & Woman, Boy & Girl, 1972, by Sally Hopkins.
moneycover.alt: A two-by-two grid. In the top row there are drawings of a child in each cell, each gender ambiguous. In the bottom row are drawings of a bearded man and woman with long hair.

lobotomycopy.caption: Saturday Evening Post, 1941.
lobotomycopy.alt: Title cut from an article that says “Turning the mind inside out by Waldemar Kaempffert.”

youngjanetframe.caption: Portrait of Janet Frame, believed to have been taken by John Money.
youngjanetframe.alt: Portrait of a young Janet Frame.

johnmoney1946.caption: John Money at the University of Otago, Dunedin, New Zealand, 1946.
johnmoney1946.alt: Portrait of a young John Money.

seacliffplan.caption: First floor plan of the Seacliff Lunatic Asylum, 1881.
seacliffplan.alt: Hand drawn floor plan of the Seacliff Lunatic Asylum.

seacliffnurses.caption: Nurses on the front lawn of Seacliff, 1890.
seacliffnurses.alt: Nurses in white gowns stand spread on the lawn in front of an old castle-like structure that is the Seacliff Asylum.

johnmoney1947.caption: Scanned from John Money: A Tribute (on the occasion of his 70th birthday), © 1991 by The Haworth Press

paraphilias.caption: From John Money, Venuses Penuses, 441, 1986.
paraphilias.alt: A table of 33 “Paraphilias” such as “FROTTEURISM”, rub against stranger, or “GERONTOPHILIA,” elder, or “NARRATOPHILIA,” erotic talk. Some words are marked as a “New Term formed from Greek root” in collaboration with a John Hopkins Professor of Greek, such as “STIGMATOPHILIA,” piercing; tattoo.

gidschematic.caption: “[T]he sequence of determinants or events that lead to the differentiation of gender identity in childhood or adulthood. [...] With each change in the transmission of the program of gender-identity differentiation, there exists the possibility that an error may be introduced and subsequently transmitted.” From John Money, Venuses Penuses, 224–25, 1986.
gidschematic.alt: A branching path diagram starting with “XX and XY chromosomes” and ending with “Adult gender identity/role”. The beginning points in the path are biological, such as “fetal gonads,” “fetal hormones,” or “genital appearance” whereas others are behavioral, such as “juvenile gender identity/role” or “pubertal eroticism.”

sextable.caption: Table mapping many chromosomal variations to intersex diagnoses. From Overzier, Intersexuality, 173–74, 1963.
sextable.alt: A giant, long “fusebox settings” table showing relationship between chromosomal variations and intersex diagnoses.

healthiness.caption: From John Money, Venuses Penuses, 175–76, 1986.
healthiness.alt: A table titled “Psychologic Healthiness Ratings of 94 Patients.” Each row is a “variety of hermaphroditism” such as “Adrenal female,” “True,” “Gonadal agenesis” and “male hypospadic.” Each column shows counts ranging from “Healthy” to “Severe.”

lobotomy.caption: A Saturday Evening Post profile of lobotomy pioneers Walter Freeman and James Watts: “The psychosurgeon thrusts his knife deep into that brain on either side, cuts at exactly the right plane and usually succeeds in turning an ingrowing and a harassed mind outward and in transforming a personality.” Kaempffert, “Turning the Mind Inside Out,” 1941.
lobotomy.alt: Scan of an article. One image shows surgeons in lab coats looking at an x-ray of a skull and another shows a masked nurse helping a masked surgeon put on gloves before surgery. The text of the article is about “psychosurgery.”

moneyframe1987.caption: John Money and Janet Frame at a reunion in Ōtaki, New Zealand, 1987.
moneyframe1987.alt: An elderly John Money and Janet Frame.

lavenderreport.caption: In response to the “Lavender Scare,” which linked McCarthy-era communist fears to homosexuality, the Hoey committee released this report, concluding homosexuals in government posed a security risk. The report led to President Eisenhower's 1953 Executive Order #10450, effectively barring all gay men and lesbian women from jobs in the US government.
lavenderreport.alt: The cover of a senate committee report titled “Employment of Homosexuals and Other Sex Perverts in Government.”

chromosomesgonads.caption: From John Money, Venuses Penuses, 155, 1986.
chromosomesgonads.alt: Two Tables. One is titled “Chromosomes and Rearing Contradictory; 19 cases” and the other “Gonads and Rearing Contradictory; 20 cases”.

stanley.caption: “Unsolicited declaration of desire for sex reassignment given by the boy-to-girl patient” from Money and Ehrhardt, Man & Woman, Boy & Girl, 173, 1972.
stanley.alt: A scan of lined paper upon which is written, in a child’s handwriting: “Dear Dr. I do not want to be a boy. I want to be a girl. Just my sisters. From Stanley.”

andreaboy.caption: Drawings from Andrea, a patient who “[s]elf-declared as a boy for the first time” from Money and Ehrhardt, Man & Woman, Boy & Girl, 288, 1972.
andreaboy.alt: Two drawings by a child. The first shows three bodies which are crossed out. The second shows a smiling person with short hair and a t-shirt, captioned with the words “Father Andrea Boy.”

andrea.caption: “First drawing of self” from Money and Ehrhardt, Man & Woman, Boy & Girl, 286, 1972.
andrea.alt: Child’s drawing of a person with long legs and arms stretched out. Beneath it says “Andrea” and another word not legible.

twins.caption: Janet Reimer with her identical twins Brian and Bruce, ca. 1965.
twins.alt: A woman, Janet Reimer, seated on a chair, smiling and holding two babies.

youngreimer.caption: Portraits of a young Brenda Reimer.
youngreimer.alt: Two photographs. One of a studio portrait of young Brenda with shoulder-length hair. The other is a toddler in a dress, walking on a grassy lawn.

genderfeedback.caption: A feedback diagram showing interactions between “the organism and the environment” that lead to behavioral sex differences over time. Reinisch et al., “Sex Differences in Developmental Milestones during the First Year of Life,” 1991.
genderfeedback.alt: A diagram that shows the diverging paths of males and females from “gestation” to “infancy/childhood” to “adolescence” to “adulthood” to finally “older years.” The diagram shows increasing differentiation from birth to puberty and the ongoing feedback interaction with “environmental influences” and the “perception of environment.”

tomboyism.caption: From Money and Ehrhardt, Man & Woman, Boy & Girl, 106, 1972.
tomboyism.alt: Table that lists behavioral signs of tomboyism and p values for different conditions such as Progestin-induced hermaphroditism or Adrenogenital syndrome. Signs that are recorded include “known to self or mother as tomboy,” “preference of male versus female friends,” and “lacking interest in jewelry, perfume and hair styling.”

davidreimer.caption: David Reimer (1965–2004).
davidreimer.alt: Portrait of a teenage David Reimer.

reimermarriage.caption: David and Jane on their wedding day, 1990.
reimermarriage.alt: David and Jane are seen smiling in the back of a limousine. Both are dressed in white, smiling, and Jane is holding a bouquet.

moneyapartment.caption: John Money's apartment in Baltimore.
moneyapartment.alt: A two-story building painted in a bright red with light blue-trimmed windows.

moneycollection.caption: Money amassed a collection of over 400 works from Australia, New Zealand, West Africa, and Baltimore.
moneycollection.alt: A room filled with what appears to be indigenous artworks, woven vessels, and African masks.

boviepatent.caption: “Another object of this invention is to provide an electro-surgical apparatus adapted to provide a plurality of types of current over a wide power range, […] with adjustments and controls particularly suited to the convenience of the operating surgeon and his assistants, in order that the proper current may be applied to the patient [...] without danger of confusion […].”
boviepatent.alt: Patent diagram dated July 14, 1931 of an electrocautery surgery device shaped like a handgun. The diagram details the mechanisms and circuitry of the device.

antiquebovie.caption: Nameplate of a 1930s-era portable Bovie electro-surgical device.
antiquebovie.alt: Black and gold metal nameplate that says “Portable Bovie Electro-Surgical Unit” and additional information related to its serial number, voltage, etc. It has a dirty and worn look.

artificialvagina.caption: “An individual, 26 years of age, had been brought up as a female. There was a minute penis, a bifid scrotum, undescended testes and a tiny vagina. The patient had female characteristics, was engaged to marry a man and requested the construction of an artificial vagina. The penis was so small that it never could have been used in coitus, and the character of the patient was so typically female that we consented to attempt to make an artificial vagina.” From Young, Genital Abnormalities, Hermaphroditism and Related Adrenal Diseases, 292–301, 1937.
artificialvagina.alt: Hand-drawn medical illustrations showing three steps in the surgical construction of an artificial vagina. Dated 1936.

sekundar.caption: A Biblical narrative upended. “Eve first, then Adam! […] Eve differentiates, unaided, whereas Adam is depicted as needing the help of the archangel who appears with an injection needle loaded with testosterone, the masculizing hormone, shoots up Eve, and lo! Adam comes forth.” From Money, Gay, Straight, and In-Between, 19, 1988.
sekundar.alt: A two-part comic. In the first part Adam is seated beneath a tree with a stitched up incision beneath his ribs. Beneath him it says “primar.” Above him a bone is transforming into Eve. Little angels are helping with this. Beneath her it says “sekundar.” In the second comic, Eve leans against the tree, beneath her it says “primar.” Standing next to her stands Adam, half male, half female, whom the angels are injecting with testosterone. Beneath “him” it says “sekundar”.

intersexrightsmap.caption: Countries that protect intersex children from non-consensual medical intervention.

intersexprotest.caption: Intersex rights activists outside the Lurie Children’s Hospital of Chicago, 2018.
intersexprotest.alt: A group of activists standing outside a children’s hospital. They’re carrying a banner: “END intersex surgery.”

hermafrodite.caption: From Ambroise Paré, Des monstres et prodiges, 1585.
hermafrodite.alt: A illustration titled "Pourtraict d'un hermafrodite homme & femme." It depicts a person standing with their arm raised, displaying anatomical features which could be either male or female.

hijra.caption: Hijras in Bangladesh, 2010.
hijra.alt: Five South Asian Hijras embracing each other for a group photo. They’re wearing colorful saris and smiling at the camera.

wewa.caption: The late We:wa, a celebrated Zuni textile artist, weaver, and potter. As a Łamana (Two Spirit), they took on a mixture of women’s and men’s typical roles and skills. In this photograph, they wore traditional women’s attire and weaved on a backstrap loom, typically a men’s skill. Photo ca. 1871.
wewa.alt: Wewa sits on the floor of the room, clad in traditional Zuni clothes and weaving a textile on a backstrap loom.

priscilla.caption: From The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert, 1994.
priscilla.alt: Movie still from The Adventures of Priscilla Queen of the Desert, showing the three main characters, one of which is trans and the other two who are dressed in colorful, flamboyant drag outfits.

invertido.caption: “Invertido Sexual” from Gómez, La Mala Vida en Buenos Aires, 1908.
invertido.alt: A grainy old photograph of a feminine-presenting person with curly hair wearing an intricately patterned garment. The person stands with their hands on their hips, contemplatively looking up.

lavenderwheel.caption: “When Capt. George Raines testified before the committee, he submitted this diagram, which he had used to teach his psychiatry students at Georgetown University. Raines believed that homosexuality was contained to some degree in all personalities. (Records of the U.S. Senate, RG 46)”

buckangel.caption: Buck Angel (1962–), trans porn star, producer, activist, and educator.
buckangel.alt: A studio portrait of a bald and bearded Buck Angel looking intently at the camera. He is wearing a white tank top that reveals arm and chest tattoos.

stepford.caption: BA: combine (or use both) of these or similar, vintage identical-ish women and men

file_print: Pentland 1991 average face from eigenfaces paper.png
file_web: Pentland 1991 average face from eigenfaces paper-Enhanced.webp
file_web_thb: Pentland 1991 average face from eigenfaces paper-Enhanced.webp
pentlandface.caption: Average face from Pentland, 1991.
pentlandface.alt: A greyscale image of that depicts a hazy male face with short, dark hair.

mikemikeface.caption: Faces of the “average” Sydneysider, by Mike Mike, 2004.
mikemikeface.alt: Two faces. A female face and male face. Around each there is a blurry blue backdrop. The images have a soft, idealized quality to them.

galton.caption: Francis Galton, 71, featured in one of his own anthropometry cards, created on his visit to Alphonse Bertillon's Criminal Identification Laboratory in Paris, 1893.
galton.alt: A card with empty lines for measurements to be entered. At the center of the card is a photograph of Francis Galton, taken from the side and the front, resembling a modern mugshot.

galtoncomposite.caption: Composite portraiture device from Galton, Inquiries Into Human Faculty and Its Development, 1883.
galtoncomposite.alt: Illustration of a contraption with a camera on the left and on the right a stack of portraits that have been pinned to line up.

galtoncriminality.caption: Galton’s attempts to use multiple exposure portraiture to reconstruct “criminal types.”
galtoncriminality.alt: Composite portraits by Galton. There are two blurred portraits, one labeled “8 Cases” and the other “4 Cases.” The portraits show men with cropped hair, with the upper torso blurry, suggesting multiple overlapping photos. The image is subtitled “2 Of the many Criminal Types.”

eigenfaces.caption: The first four principal components of face images, sometimes called “eigenfaces.”
eigenfaces.alt: A sequence of four photos showing blurred faces, where facial features are either lightened or darkened in regions like the eye cavities or mouth area.

wuzhang.caption: “Criminal” and “Non-criminal” ID card image data samples from Wu and Zhang, 2016.

wuzhang1.caption: “Criminal” ID card image data samples from Wu and Zhang, 2016.
wuzhang1.alt: Headshots of three men. They are slightly frowning, wearing dark colored clothes, and one wears a necklace.

wuzhang2.caption: “Non-criminal” ID card image data samples from Wu and Zhang, 2016.
wuzhang2.alt: Headshots of three men. Their facial expressions are neutral and appear to be wearing white collared shirts and dark blazers.

todorov.caption: Computer reconstructions of “nice” (left) and “mean” (right) faces based on experimental data, courtesy of Alex Todorov.

todorov1.caption: Computer reconstruction of a “nice” face based on experimental data, courtesy of Alex Todorov.
todorov1.alt: A computer animation of a bald head. The face has feminine features and raised eyebrows and slightly smiling.

todorov2.caption: Computer reconstruction of a “mean” face based on experimental data, courtesy of Alex Todorov.
todorov2.alt: A computer animation of a bald head. The face has masculine features and lowered eyebrows and slightly scowling.

prendergast.caption: Courtroom drawing of Patrick Eugene Joseph Prendergast, 1894.
prendergast.alt: Drawing of a man seated in a chair. He has downturned lips suggesting a frown. The image is subtitled “Assassin Patrick Eugene Joseph Prendergast, To Be Hanged Today.”

lips.caption: From Victor G. Rocine, “The Seat of Love, and the Story that Lips Tell,” 1907.
lips.alt: Clipping from an old publication containing drawings of 3 kinds of lips. Thin, neutral lips described as “Lips of Judge Cooley” beneath which it says “honesty is seen in these lips, but not affection.” Followed by “Mouth and Lips of Prendergast, the Murderer,” “A protruding under lip is a bad sign. Such an under lip denotes crime and vicious instincts.” Beneath which are the “Lips of Mrs. Meyer,” “A loving mouth has large and full lips. The lips of Mrs. Meyer indicate missionary tendencies, a love for the public and public work.”

savage_lovecast_579.caption: From episode #579 of the Savage Lovecast.
savage_lovecast_579.alt: From episode #579 of the Savage Lovecast.

wangkosinski.caption: Facial composites from Wang and Kosinski, 2018.

wangkosinski1.caption: Heterosexual facial composites from Wang and Kosinski, 2018.
wangkosinski1.alt: A masculine and feminine appearing face. The masculine face seems bald with a mustache and goatee, and a wide jaw. The feminine face has long, straight, light-colored hair and possibly wearing eyeliner and mascara, and a smiling expression.

wangkosinski2.caption: Homosexual facial composites from Wang and Kosinski, 2018.
wangkosinski2.alt: A masculine and feminine appearing face. The masculine face has short hair, the faint outlines of glasses, no facial hair, a narrower jaw, and wide open eyes. The feminine face has long dark hair, dark eyebrows, a narrower face, possibly wearing eyeliner, and a neutral expression.

selfie.caption: Selfies of the author, illustrating the visual effect of varying camera angle, grooming, and stylish glasses.
selfie.alt: Two photos of a masculine face. The first shows him without glasses and a beard, with the photo taken from below, emphasizing his jaw size. In the second, he is wearing glasses, sporting short stubble, and the photo is taken from above, causing his jaw to appear smaller.

rocine.caption: Supposed “[d]egeneracy seen in [the] eyes, eyebrows, nose, lips, jaw, hair and pose,” from Rocine, 1910.
rocine.alt: A woman with wavy, short hair. She is unsmiling and has a perhaps defiant or contemplative expression.

mugshots.caption: Table IV, “Fisionomie di criminali Russe” [Physiognomies of Russian criminals] from Lombroso, La donna delinquente, la prostituta e la donna normale, 1893.
mugshots.alt: A sequence of 25 headshots of women. All are frowning and most have their lips downturned. Some stare into the distance while others look directly into the camera.

target.caption: From Abi Bechtel's tweet, June 1, 2015.
target.alt: A sign to a supermarket aisle labeled: “Building Sets” and “Girls’ Building Sets.”

tocalife.caption: Still from Toca Life Stories, a series released by Toca Boca in 2020.
tocalife.alt: A Toca Boca scene displaying diverse and non-binary characters.

phrenologicalbust.caption: A phrenological bust from Pacheco, Esposición sumaria del sistema frenológico del doctor Gall, 1835.
phrenologicalbust.alt: A bust with numbered regions dividing up sections of the head. Beneath is a brain labeled with numbers across its regions.

lovelace.caption: Augusta Ada King, Countess of Lovelace.
lovelace.alt: An oil painting of Ada Lovelace.

criminallesbians.caption: “Criminal” lesbian couple from Lombroso, La donna delinquente, la prostituta e la donna normale, 423, 1893.
criminallesbians.alt: Two women. The woman on the right is dressed in traditional feminine clothing of the time, the one on the left has short hair and appears to be wearing masculine clothes. They embrace as they defiantly face the camera.

agriculture.caption: Timucan men cultivating the land while Timucan women sow maize or beans. From Le Moyne de Morgues, Brevis narratio eorum quae in Florida Americai provincia Gallis acciderunt, XXI, 1591 with engravings by Theodor de Bry (1528–98).
agriculture.alt: Barely clad men and women work a field. The women carry baskets of seeds and are sowing them in the field, while the men are bent over, laboring on the land with shovels.

hunt.caption: The “Man the Hunter” trope as depicted by David Livingstone in Missionary Tales and Researches in South Africa, 1857.
hunt.alt: A group of dark skinned men throw spears at an elephant, who already has many spears poking out of its backside.

powerloom.caption: Power-loom weaving in Great Britain, 1835.
powerloom.alt: Illustration of a factory filled with powerlooms and workers, primarily women, operating them.

housework.caption: Bettye Lane, Wages for Housework at International Women's Day March, New York, March 12, 1977.
housework.alt: A group of protesters, primarily girls and women, marching with a banner that says “Wages for housework.”

najell.caption: A Najell AB baby carrier as advertised on Najell.com.
najell.alt: A man and woman walking together. The man is carrying a baby in a baby carrier strapped to his chest.

artificialwomb.caption: An “artificial uterus” from Emanuel M. Greenberg, US Patent No. 2,723,660, 1955.
artificialwomb.alt: A patent diagram showing a fetus suspended in a vat connected to a series of labeled devices such as “thermostat,” “blood pump,” “water heater,” “artificial kidney,” “liquid food,” etc.

boeree.caption: Selfies of Liv Boeree without (first) and with (second) beauty filters applied, 2021.
boeree.alt: Liv Boeree without and with a beauty filter applied.

faceapp.caption: Selfies of the author unmodified and with various FaceApp filters, 2021.
faceapp.alt: The author’s face transformed by filters to appear young, wearing lipstick, puffy, and old.

doginternet.caption: The New Yorker, July 5, 1993.
doginternet.alt: A dog, seated at a desk in front of a computer, stares down at another dog. It explains “On the Internet, nobody knows you’re a dog.”

tataouineatnight.caption: View of Tataouine, Tunisia at night, 2012. The city inspired the name of Luke Skywalker’s fictional home planet of Tatooine.
tataouineatnight.alt: Dusk view of a barren desert landscape cut through with brightly lights indicating a settlement that carved downwards into the desert ground.

moseisley.caption: Luke and C-3PO enter the Mos Eisley cantina in Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope, 1977.
moseisley.alt: Luke and C3PO peer into a seedy bar filled with different kinds of alien types, who are staring back at them.

oola.caption: “A cosplay of Jabba’s slave, Oola” at the Anaheim Star Wars Celebration, 2015.
oola.alt: A women whose skin is painted green, wearing green prosthetics, a mesh dress, and a collar, leading her to look like the the Star Wars character Oola.

americangothic.caption: BA: Or maybe American Gothic starwars if we can get permission.

beebo.caption: “Lost, lonely, boyishly appealing—this is Beebo Brinker—who never really knew what she wanted—until she came to Greenwich Village and found the love that smoulders in the shadows of the twilight world.” From the cover of lesbian pulp fiction novel Beebo Brinker by Ann Bannon, 1962. Art by Robert McGinnis.
beebo.alt: A woman standing alone in an urban environment at night, clutching a woven basket. She is wearing bright red lipstick and a green coat.

bathhouse.caption: Domenico (il Passignano) Cresti, Bathers at San Niccolò, 1600.
bathhouse.alt: A bathhouse scene at the edge of a town with a large castle. The bathhouse is filled with scantily clad men lounging, dancing in the water, and playing with each other.

monticello.caption: Thomas Jefferson’s vegetable garden at Monticello, Virginia, 2005.

interstates.caption: “Relief traffic map of the recommended interregional system. The height of the traffic bands indicates approximately the average density of traffic [...]. The mounting spires at the principal cities picture the great increases of traffic to be expected on sections of routes traversing the cities.” From the 1944 Interregional Highways report.
interstates.alt: A model relief map of the United States showing lines at varying heights tracing the streets, with heights particularly pronounced near urban centers.

densitymap.caption: MK: will be deleted after finalizing map data sheet

smallfarming.caption: Small-scale agriculture in Vietnam, 2005.
smallfarming.alt: Landscape divided into small plots of various vegetables, around which men and women are bent over, working the land.

suburb.caption: Dallas suburbs and skyline, 2009.
suburb.alt: A landscape photo, in the foreground are rows of identical houses, and in the background are the highrises of the Dallas city skyline.

castro.caption: Castro District, San Francisco, 2006.
castro.alt: A queer flag rises above the Castro neighborhood.

worldsfair.caption: The General Motors “Futurama” exhibit, New York World's Fair, 1939.
worldsfair.alt: A group of people seated on a viewing platform, looking down at a model of a city.

princehenry.caption: A 1786 bid to establish monarchy in the United States included an offer to Prince Henry of Prussia to become king.
princehenry.alt: Portrait of Prince Henry of Prussia.

streetscene.caption: Lower East Side of New York, ca. 1890.
streetscene.alt: A bustling street scene. People and horse-drawn wagons crowd the road.

packard.caption: Abandoned factories of the former Packard Automotive Plant, Detroit, 2009.
packard.status: included in the book(-06-06.pdf) as an alt for a video keokuk

keokuk.caption: Keokuk, Iowa, per the US Census, is approximately 90% white and 2% foreign-born, and had a population of 9,792 in 2021, down from a mid-20th century high of over 16,000.

pinebluff.caption: Pine Bluff, Arkansas lost 18% of its population from 2010 to 2019, in part due to vanishing manufacturing jobs. About 30% ot its 41,000 remaining residents live below the poverty line.

ruraltrump.caption: Schuylkill County, Pennsylvania, 2016: per 2022 Census estimates, 93% white and 2% foreign-born.

redlining.caption: Map of New Orleans created by the US Federal Government’s Home Owners’ Loan Corporation between 1935 and 1940, illustrating redlining. Color-coded grades were assigned to neighborhoods reflecting their “mortgage security,” from “A” (green–deemed safe by banks and mortgage lenders) to “D” (red–“hazardous”). The race and class of residents was factored into the calculation of risk grades. See Nelson et al., “Mapping Inequality,” 2021.
redlining.alt: A map of New Orleans, showing the city divided into zones colored green, yellow, blue, and red.

blackfarmers.caption: “Farmer waiting for supplies which he is buying cooperatively at Roanoke Farms, North Carolina,” 1938.
blackfarmers.alt: A black farmer standing on a horse-drawn wagon.

jesusland.alt: A map showing regions labeled “United States of Canada” and “Jesusland.”

votersuppression.caption: Political cartoon by Thomas Nast for Harper's Weekly, March 16, 1867.
votersuppression.alt: Cartoon of a black man placing a ballot, surrounded by white men grimacing at him and staring at him distrustfully. A banner says “The White Man’s Ticket.”

notke.caption: Bernt Notke, Danse Macabre in St. Nicholas Church, Tallinn, Estonia, ca. 1486–93.
notke.alt: A painting showing skeletal figures of death dancing with mortals.

file_web: Dance of Death Philadelphia Museum of Art 1974-179-511v1-dig2018 EDIT Contrast.webp
file_web_thb: Dance of Death Philadelphia Museum of Art 1974-179-511v1-dig2018 EDIT Contrast.webp
danse.caption: Michael Wolgemut, Dance of Death, from The Nuremberg Chronicle, 1493.
danse.alt: Woodcut print of skeletons playing music and dancing as a skeleton crawls out of the grave.

danseploughman.caption: “The Plowman” from Hans Holbein's Simolachri, Historie, e Figure de la Morte, 1549.
danseploughman.alt: A man plows a field with a horse-drawn plow. A skeleton runs alongside, whipping the horses.

dansechild.caption: “The Child” from Holbein, 1549.
dansechild.alt: Two adults stare in distress as a skeleton leads their small child out of the building.

dansefarmer.caption: “Adam Tills the Soil” from Holbein, 1549.
dansefarmer.alt: Adam tills the soil shoulder to shoulder with a skeleton, who also works the soil with a stick. In the background, Eve is seen nursing a baby.

san.caption: Mothers of the San people, Namibia.
san.alt: Mothers of the San people are gathered around a baby held by one of the women. That woman also carries another small child in a sling.

sami.caption: A Sámi family in Finland, 1936.
sami.alt: A group of traditionally clad men and women, holding small children and a dog, in front of a canvas structure.

plague.caption: The Great Plague of Marseille in 1720 (the last major bubonic plague outbreak in Western Europe) as depicted by Michel Serre in 1721.
plague.alt: A group of French officers mounted on horses, and health workers with their face wrapped, contend with vast mounds of plague-stricken bodies.

triumphdeath.caption: The Triumph of Death by Pieter Bruegel the Elder, 1562.
triumphdeath.alt: Hordes of skeletons lay waste to the few remaining humans. Neither kings nor peasants are spared.

farmingmachines1.caption: JM: Dropped in the print version

farmingmachines2.caption: Patrick Bell's reaping machine, 1851.
farmingmachines2.alt: A man operates an elaborate contraption, pushed by two horses, that is reaping a field of wheat.

babyboom.caption: Babies born in a maternity hospital in Paris on January 1, 1946.
babyboom.alt: Two nurses proudly display 13 newborn babies.

bothhadsyphilis.caption: By 1943, syphilis was treatable with penicillin, as advertised by World War II era poster campaigns.
bothhadsyphilis.alt: A vintage poster showing two men, between them it says “Both of these men had SYPHILIS.” One man is playing with his kid, wife and child in the background. It says “He took his Syphilis shots every week until cured.” Below a lonely man, blind and on crutches, sits alone – “he didn’t take his shots.”

tractorharvest.caption: “Mrs. Trelle drives the tractor while Mr. Trelle operates the binder while harvesting their wheat crop.” Alberta, 1928.
tractorharvest.alt: A woman drives a tractor. A man sits beside her, riding on an attached device that harvests the field.

arableland.caption: Arable land use under different productivity scenarios, from LtG, 50, 1972.
arableland.alt: A plot showing the exponential growth of arable land. It then shows possible scenarios “agricultural land needed at present productivity level,” “at double present productivity,” “at quadruple present productivity,” all projected to eventually outpace the “total world supply of arable land.”

worldmodel.caption: Stock and flow diagram of the World3 computer model, from LtG, 102–103, 1972.
worldmodel.alt: Dozens of interconnected nodes representing the World3 model.

carryingcapacity.caption: “[A] population growing in a limited environment can approach the ultimate carrying capacity of that environment in several possible ways. It can adjust smoothly to an equillibrium below the environmental limit [...]. It can over-shoot the limit and then die back again in either a smooth or an oscillatory way [...]. Or it can overshoot the limit and in the process decrease the ultimate carrying capacity by consuming some necessary nonrenewable resource.” From LtG, 91–92, 1972.
carryingcapacity.alt: How population growth can change as it approaches the carrying capacity of its environment.

co2.caption: Model of carbon dioxide concentration in the atmosphere based on measurements at Mauna Loa, Hawaii. From LtG, 72, 1972.
co2.alt: Plot showing predicted and observed CO2 concentrations predicted by a LtG model. The model predicts a drastic rise from 322 ppm in 1971 to 380 ppm by 2000.

standardrun.caption: “The 'standard' world model assumes no major changes in the physical, economic, or social relationships that have historically governed the development of the world system. [...] Population growth is finally halted by a rise in the death rate due to decrease in food and medical services.” LtG, 124, 1972.
standardrun.alt: Plot detailing the standard run scenario of the LtG world model.

worldpop.caption: BA: Need to find data and replot nicely.

condom.caption: Giacomo Casanova, the famous Italian adventurer, entertaining sex workers by blowing up condoms to check for holes, 1872.
condom.alt: Giacomo Casanova and another man test condoms by blowing them up as the ladies they’re with heartily laugh on.

thepill.caption: A woman holding a package of birth control pills, New York, 1972.
thepill.alt: A package of birth control pills, embellished with a butterfly illustration, in a clamshell container.

file_web_thb: Gillian Frank on Twitter Birth Control Review ERzwSesVAAAijzL-Enhanced.webp
birthcontrolreview.caption: Birth Control Review, November 1923, in The Selected Papers of Margaret Sanger.
birthcontrolreview.alt: The cover page of “Birth Control Review” depicts a woman in agony chained to a large iron ball that says “unwanted babies.”

farmchild.caption: Eight-year-old Jennie Camillo is pictured picking cranberries in Turkeytown, New Jersey, during the summer of 1910. Photo by Lewis Hine.
farmchild.alt: A small girl in a white dress stands alone in a field, carrying upon her shoulder a wooden box filled with cranberries.

factorychildren.caption: Photographer Lewis Hine notes: “Many youngsters here. Some boys were so small they had to climb up on the spinning frame to mend the broken threads and put back the empty bobbins.” At the Bibb Mill in Macon, Georgia, in January, 1909.
factorychildren.alt: A large industrial textile machine, connected to a spinning belt, upon which stand two small, barefoot boys who are mending the machine.

bigfamily.caption: “Mrs. Cecilia Wega, 39, of Castle Shannon [...] has 13 children yet finds time and energy to put in 48 hours a week hard work as a laborer for the Pennsylvania Railroad.” Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, 1943.
bigfamily.alt: A family’s 13 children stand in increasing height, from small toddler girls and boys, to the tallest teenage sons. At the end stands the middle-aged Mrs. Celia Wega, who is also carrying a 3-month-old.

charlottesville.caption: Demonstrators at the “Unite the Right” rally in Charlottesville, Virginia, on August 12, 2017.
charlottesville.alt: Various demonstrators, all male and wearing khaki pants, carrying flags with confederate and Nazi iconography.

dragons.caption: Here be dragons. From the Psalter World Map, ca. 1260.
dragons.alt: Two dragons drawn on the margins of an 11th century map.

wildpostcard.caption: “A Mountain Stream In Autumn,” Asheville Postcard Company, ca. 1912.
wildpostcard.alt: A wilderness scene showing a forest of green, yellow, orange and red hues through which runs a stream.

farmpostcard.caption: “Home of J.E. Ranch, Waverly, N.Y.,” Asheville Postcard Company, ca. 1912.
farmpostcard.alt: A farm consisting of a large red barn and several farm houses, all surrounded by lush green fields and forest.

factorypostcard.caption: Western Clock Factory, La Salle, Illinois, E.C. Kropp Co., ca. 1920.
factorypostcard.alt: Idealized illustration of a large red factory complex with smoke rising from its three chimneys.

factorypostcard1.caption: Western Clock Factory, La Salle, Illinois, E.C. Kropp Co., ca. 1920.

villagepostcard.caption: Rockport Harbor, Rockport, Maine, ca. 1930–45.
villagepostcard.alt: Idyllic scene of a village perched on a hill overlooking a calm harbor.

viewmaster.caption: A View-Master stereo viewer.
viewmaster.alt: A box for the View-Master stereo viewer today, on which is a smiling child looking through the plastic View-Master device.

ruinstown.caption: Abandoned homes in Detroit, 2017.
ruinstown.alt: Three large family homes in varying states of decay.

spagnuolo.caption: Giuseppe Spagnuolo has for a quarter century been the last remaining inhabitant of Roscigno Vecchia, a village in the Cilento area of Campania, southern Italy.
spagnuolo.alt: An old man sits alone in the plaza of an Italian village, smoking a pipe.
spagnuolo.status: used in book (final), excluded on the web

ruinsitaly.caption: The old town of Balestrino, Italy, abandoned in 1953 after it was struck by multiple earthquakes.
ruinsitaly.alt: A scene of abandoned villages, covered in growths of moss and other plants, seemingly crumbling into disrepair.

akiya.caption: Derelict homes in Wajima, Japan.
akiya.alt: Abandoned homes covered in rust and surrounded by unkempt gardens.

robert.caption: A Hermit Praying in the Ruins of a Roman Temple by Hubert Robert, ca. 1760.
robert.alt: A vast, once opulent Roman temple, is now seen in a state of decay, populated by plants, roosting birds, and a hermit who is praying at a makeshift altar. Behind him, three women are sneaking to steal his flowers. The painting evokes the feeling of a once great civilization now lost to time.

ruinsfarm.caption: Abandoned farmhouse near Seneca, New York, 2010.
ruinsfarm.alt: A scene of abundant foliage among which is an abandoned farmhouse.

charlottesweb.caption: Illustration by Garth Williams from E.B. White, Charlotte’s Web, 1952.
charlottesweb.alt: A scene from Charlotte’s Web. A large spider’s web stretches across the entrance to a barn. A small piglet smiles and looks up at the spider in the web.

shadyglade.caption: From Bill Peet, Farewell to Shady Glade, 1976.
shadyglade.alt: “Then just beyond a hill not more than fifty yards to the east he spotted the rumblers. Monstrous machines gouging out whole clumps of trees in one scoop, a ton of earth in one bite, leaving nothing but their giant tracks on the barren ground. And they were heading straight for Shady Glade! ‘We’re in for it,’ muttered the raccoon as he scurried down the tree to rejoin his friends.”

robotfactory.caption: Robots at work in Tesla's Fremont factory, 2017.
robotfactory.alt: View of a factory floor. Large red robotic arms, in motion at work on vehicle chassis, are lined side by side until the back of the factory.

lightsout.caption: Lights-out production facility.
lightsout.alt: A facility devoid of any humans, where machines work alone in the dark.

robotport.caption: Fully automated straddle carriers (AutoStrads) move shipping containers at the Port of Los Angeles, the busiest shipping port in the US, 2016.
robotport.alt: A bustling shipping port with large container cranes in the background. In front of them are tall red, automated straddle carriers.

containership.caption: Maersk Line container ships in port, Rotterdam, 2019.
containership.alt: Two large container ships stacked with thousands of containers.

datacenter.caption: Inside a Google data center in Douglas County, Georgia.

amazonwarehouse.caption: Barriers divide this Amazon warehouse so that humans and robots may safely work together.
amazonwarehouse.alt: A human works alongside mesh walls, yellow bins, blue pallots, and a large robotic arm.

amazoncage.caption: “Disclosed herein is a human transport device and associated system to transport a user within an active workspace.” From Amazon employees Wurman et al., US Patent No. 9,280,157, 2016.
amazoncage.alt: A robotic base mounted with a mesh cage. Inside the cage is a controller and outside is a robotic arm.

agrobot.caption: An Agrobot robotic strawberry harvester, 2019.
agrobot.alt: A large robot rolls down the rows of a strawberry field.

droids.caption: Kenny Baker as R2-D2 and Anthony Daniels as C-3P0 on the set of Star Wars, 1977.
droids.alt: Kenny Baker pokes his head out of the top of his R2-D2 costume, looking up at Anthony Daniels, wearing the legs of this C-3P0 costume.

fanucarm.caption: The FANUC M-2000iA, demonstrating its 1.7t payload capacity.
fanucarm.alt: A massive yellow robotic arm lifts a car into the air.

waymo.caption: A Waymo self-driving car in suburban Mountain View, California, 2017.
waymo.alt: The small, distinctive Waymo car with cameras and sensors mounted to its roof and front side.

cowtraffic.caption: A cow and traffic share the road in Jaipur, India, 1999.
cowtraffic.alt: A lone cow stands on the center median, surrounded by a flow of cars, scooters, bicycles and a camel-drawn cart.

mumbaitraffic.caption: Traffic in Mumbai, India, 2016.
mumbaitraffic.alt: Gridlocked traffic consisting of cars, scooters, rickshaws, buses, and pedestrians.

roadtrain.caption: A road train, Northern Territory, Australia, 2005.
roadtrain.alt: A tanker truck with four semi-trailers stretched across a road that’s surrounded by Australia’s characteristic red earth.

bigfarmbots.caption: A fleet harvesting soybeans in Mato Grosso state, Brazil, 2008.
bigfarmbots.alt: Aerial photograph of 25 combine harvesters driving in V formation across a soybean field.

farmdrone.caption: Agricultural fields are increasingly becoming digital, abstract surfaces.
farmdrone.alt: A drone scans an agricultural field. The field is covered by a surface of spatialized data.

glowinggreenhouse.caption: Aerial photograph of Dutch greenhouses by German photographer Tom Hegen, 2019.
glowinggreenhouse.alt: Aerial night photo shows green houses stretching to the horizon. Some are glowing with magenta or orange light, while others stand dark.

greenhouses.caption: A farmer's home surrounded by an array of greenhouses, the Netherlands, 2017.
greenhouses.alt: Greenhouses, some glowing with orange light, cover all ground visible in the image with the exception of where there stands a small traditional farmhouse.

communitygarden.caption: Cadillac Urban Gardens in Southwest Detroit, 2012.
communitygarden.alt: Children and some adults tend to a garden consisting of rows of industrial crates repurposed as raised beds.

rooftopgreenhouse.caption: Lufa Farms' rooftop greenhouses in Montreal, 2013.
rooftopgreenhouse.alt: Rows of greenhouses mounted atop a warehouse.

autoverticalfarm.caption: An automated vertical farm in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, 2021.
autoverticalfarm.alt: A robot moves amidst densely packed shelves of greens. The farm is illuminated by magenta light.

wildlifecorridor.caption: A wildlife crossing in Sudbury, Ontario, completed in 2012.
wildlifecorridor.alt: A remote rural highway crossed by a grassy overpass connecting the forests on either side.

greenbelt.caption: The formerly militarized border separating East and West Germany has been converted to a nature reserve known as the German Green Belt.
greenbelt.alt: Yellow agricultural fields are separated by a jagged strip of green: the grass and trees that make up the greenbelt.

climatemigration.caption: “The river that once flowed through the Nuevo Paraiso Indigenous community is now just a stream. Residents depend on it for all their water needs and are afraid it will completely dry up soon.” Alta Verapaz, Guatemala. From Lustgarten, “Where Will Everyone Go?”, 2020.
climatemigration.alt: Women and children carry plastic bottles under arm and colorful jugs of water atop their heads. They are standing atop river rocks, and a small stream is visible in the background.

stelarc.caption: Stelarc, Third Hand, Tokyo, Yokohama, Nagoya, 1976–1980.
stelarc.alt: Stelarc appears nude wearing a mechanical arm prosthesis mounted to his right arm while a series of tubes, electromechanical boxes and wires are fastened across his body.

strike.caption: Woolworth's employees on strike, New York, 1937.
strike.alt: Women dressed in their Woolworth’s uniforms smile and cheer, holding the sign “Sit-down // Woolworth Workers Strike // Help us win 40 hr. week // Dep’t store emp. union.”

thelwall.caption: A political cartoon depicting John Thelwall, 1795.
thelwall.status: excluded in the book(-06-06.pdf) and the web, marking as false

jetsonbutton.caption: In 1960s animated sitcom The Jetsons, patriarch George Jetson regularly complains of his heavy work load under tyrannical boss Mr. Spacely: pushing a button on and off as many as five times for three hours, three days a week.
jetsonbutton.alt: George Jetson sits in front of an elaborate console of buttons and levers, his finger hovering over a button, as he stares with resignation at his boss who is yelling at him from a screen overhead.

binning.caption: Many superimposed renditions of “Do you identify as non-binary?” binned into 10 random age range buckets (average probabilities in black, 90% confidence intervals in yellow).
